messages: e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:19): instead of one oracle server is it possible to have two oracle servers working in parallel so when the first become unaveliable the second server take the place of the first?
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:19): (...with the same instance)
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:20): its called a standby database
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:20): or, you can have them clustered
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:20): so both can work side by side
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:20): although god knows what happens in that situation when one goes down ! :)
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:21): we are talking about two seperated machines.. right?
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:21): well you could have a standy database on the same server
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:21): you can run both rac and dataguard on one machine.. but it is unsupported by oracle and sort of contradicts itself
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:21): but whats the point?
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:22): the point is... the server crashes.. what do we do?
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:24): startup your standby database on another server
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:24): change connection settings for clients, and your away
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:25): how does that sound?
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:25): thats sounds great!
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:26): thanks man
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:26): but its expensive, you can frig Oracle standard edition so that you can have a standby database, without having to use dataguard
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:26): but you have to write the scripts to copy the archive redo logs and apply them
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:26): money its not problem
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:26): no point for producoracle itself doesn't "crash"
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:27): not since 9i
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:27): 9i has a self recovery feature in pmon.. if oracle dies it comes back up ... in 99.999% of all cases
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:27): the only real point of dataguard on one machine is if you two storage systems and want to cater for data corruption..
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:28): but how often do you get that these days?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:28): it's not like you have tablespaces on tape ;)
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:28): ok but.... say the hardware of the servers dies
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:29): the cost for another machine is minimal in this context
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:29): if you fork out 50k+ for an EE license... 3k for a small standby box won't kill you :)
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:30): so maybe dataguard and another machine is the way to go for kRocKodile? if he says money is no option
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:34): if money is no problem i'd suggest a pair of x4600's .. one on the rack next to the current db ... and one at a DR site 20 miles away :)
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:34): the code of erp must be written to support standby server?
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:36): depending on your config you can either use a ip transfer or simple reconfigure the erp jdbc connection when you need to do a failover/switchover
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:39): sun opteron server yes

1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:39): maybe even create the DR site so that it looks exactly like your current site, so when you move, all workers will feel right at home, and will soon forget the disaster
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:40): if money is no option
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:41): well... if we are talking about those numbers... then.. yes money IS a problem..
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:41): the limit is 45k euro for 2 servers
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:42): for just the hardware?
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:42): but i allready have one oracle licence
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:42): you don't need a license for a standby servers
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:43): in this case 45k goes all for hardware
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:43): remember that dataguard requires enterprise edition... or you can as English` said do your own "poor mans dataguard" with scripts ... usually simpler
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:43): what do you prefer, sun/amd/xeon solaris/linux?
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:43): no idea what dataguard i
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:44): dataguard is the standby database function in oracle
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:44): i personally prefer linux but my company does not :(
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:44): yes, we use that, and in fact we used the standby in the end to move from a Physical server to the vmware'd standby server, everything went fine
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:44): English`: in a way i almost prefer the scripted way... it leaves less "gotchas" to oracle... keeps things simple
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:45): so what this script do? copy the files of instance?
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:46): copy accross archive redo logs, and then applies them to standby
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:46): this does not sound good...
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:46): of course it depends on your script, how intelligent you make it
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:47): to recover from network issues etc
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:47): i think the files is too big
1c71954f13f66b85b556f6f7332b7500 (15:47): depends on your network......
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:47): and the server will slow down if i copy every 5 min the files
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:47): the files are as big you tell them to be
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:47): you copy the database once
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:47): then apply log files
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:48): don't copy _all_ datafiles
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:48): well... i think i have to google it :>
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:49): hardware wise, 45k would get you a pair of t2000's and a diskarray
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:49): sun sparc .. if that is desirable
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:50): its a good idea to have the instance in solid state disk? (4Gb)
443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:51): have you ever seen enterprise grade solid state media?
e20ed8096d47afda16203435da629ea3 (15:51): hey are not so good?

443a9547033ec9d695ae9d29e8df98b1 (15:52): a normal solid state media has a limited number of writes... usually fine when used in a mp3 player or camera... but a database that does writes all the time.. not so good
